DOC.HEAD: Taiwan Found Liable for Official Who Ordered Murder
DOC.TEXT: The government of Taiwan is legally responsible for the acts of a military official who ordered the 1984 killing of a Taiwanese-American journalist, a federal appeals court ruled Friday. The decision by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals not only reinstates a $200 million suit by the widow of journalist Henry Liu but also links the Taiwanese government to the actions of its defense intelligence chief, Vice Admiral Wong Hsi-Lin, who has been convicted in Taiwan's own courts. ``Wong's act was committed within the scope of his employment as director of the DIB (Defense Intelligence Bureau),'' the court said. ``We conclude that the ROC (Republic of China) is liable.'' The ruling, if upheld, would virtually guarantee that Taiwan would be found liable for the murder itself, leaving only the question of damages to be resolved. ``I read the decision to say that the Republic of China is liable under California law for the murder of Henry Liu,'' said Gerard Harper, a lawyer for Helen Liu, who sued for her husband's death. ``It's the first time, to my knowledge, that in a contested case a foreign state has been held liable for a murder in the United States.'' ``My intention was to find the truth of this case, because the trial held in Taiwan was orchestrated,'' Mrs. Liu said Friday. ``The reasons why they had to kill Henry, they didn't ask in the (Taiwanese) court. ... I want people to know the real reasons, the mentality of the Taiwan regime. He (her husband) was trying to get Taiwan to be a more democratic country.'' John Martel, a lawyer for Taiwan, said he had not seen the ruling and could not say whether it would be appealed. But he said any implication that the government was responsible for the murder was false. The ruling is one of several recent decisions allowing lawsuits against foreign officials for allegedly ordering crimes in the United States. Earlier this month, a jury in Seattle found the estate of former Philippine dictator Ferdinand Marcos liable for the 1981 killings of two Philippine-American dissidents and labor union activists. Liu, 52, a Taiwanese-born U.S. citizen and author of a critical biography of Taiwan President Chiang Ching-Kuo, was shot to death in October 1984 at his home in Daly City, south of San Francisco, by gunmen who were later traced to the United Bamboo Gang in Taiwan. Military courts in Taiwan convicted five men of responsibility for the murder, including Admiral Wong, who was found to have ordered the gangsters to silence Liu. He was sentenced to life in prison. A sixth man was convicted of murder in a California court. While finding that Wong was motivated by Liu's criticism of the government as well as a personal grudge, the Taiwanese courts concluded that Taiwan's government was not responsible for Wong's unauthorized actions. U.S. District Judge Eugene Lynch cited that conclusion in September 1987 when he dismissed Mrs. Liu's suit against the government. Lynch said Wong was acting outside the scope of his employment. A U.S. court could not authorize a further inquiry into the conclusions of the Taiwanese courts, Lynch said, without involving the judiciary in sensitive areas of a foreign government's national security and intelligence affairs, causing potential embarassment to U.S. foreign policy. The appeals court, in a 3-0 ruling, disagreed with both of Lynch's conclusions. The opinion by Judge Robert Boochever said the relationship of Wong's actions and his job as intelligence chief was shown by the factual findings of the Taiwan courts. As for the Republic of China, although the suit may affect its government financially, ``it does not affront its sovereignty and can cause no more embarrassment than the exposures already made by the ROC courts,'' Boochever said.
